case_name: Hindustan Ideal Insurance Company Ltd. v. Life Insurance Corporation of India

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 82 of 1960 is an appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 17, 1958, of the Court of Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur, in case No. 16/XVIA of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 82 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 17, 1958, of the Court of Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur, in case No. 16/ XVIA of 1957.

facts.text: The Andhra Insurance Company Ltd. carried on life insurance and other insurance business.

anchor.surface_text: SARKAR J.-The Andhra Insurance Company Ltd., hereafter called the insurer, carried on life insurance and other insurance business.

facts.text: On September 1, 1956, the life insurance business of the insurer became vested in the Life Insurance Corporation of India under the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On September 1, 1956, the life insurance business of the insurer became vested in the Life Insurance Corporation of India under the provisions of the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956.

facts.text: The insurer became entitled to compensation from the Life Insurance Corporation under s. 16 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The insurer thereupon became entitled to companypensation from the Life Insurance Corporation under s. 16 of the Act.

facts.text: On February 19, 1957, the Corporation determined the amount of compensation and obtained Central Government's approval and made an offer to the insurer as provided in s. 16.

anchor.surface_text: On February 19, 1957, the Corporation having determined the amount of the companypensation and obtained the Central Governments approval made an offer of it to the insurer as provided in s. 16.

facts.text: The insurer raised certain disputes regarding the Corporation's offer of compensation.

anchor.surface_text: By the letter making the offer, the Corporation claimed various deductions. The insurer raised certain disputes.

facts.text: The Tribunal was constituted on May 25, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On August 6, 1957, the insurer made an application to the Tribunal which had been companystituted on May 25, 1957

facts.text: On August 6, 1957, the insurer made an application to the Tribunal for re-assessment of compensation and prayed for extension of time by three months from constitution of Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: On August 6, 1957, the insurer made an application to the Tribunal which had been companystituted on May 25, 1957 for an order for re-assessment of the companypensation payable to it.

facts.text: On September 21, 1957, the insurer filed another statement giving details of its claim in the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: On September 21, 1957, the insurer filed in the Tribunal another statement giving the details of its claim.

facts.text: The Tribunal by judgment dated February 17, 1958 held that insurer had no right to approach Tribunal directly, had not moved Corporation for reference, no cause shown for extension, claim time-barred, and dismissed the application.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by its judgment dated February 17, 1958 held that under s. 16 of the Act an Insurer bad numberright to approach the Tribunal directly for deciding any dispute with the Corporation regarding the amount of the companypensation

facts.text: The insurer obtained special leave from this Court to appeal against the Tribunal's judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The insurer obtained special leave from this Court to appeal against the judgment of the Tribunal and under that leave has presented this appeal.

facts.text: After leave granted, the insurer amalgamated with Hindustan Ideal Insurance Company Ltd., which was substituted as appellant.

anchor.surface_text: After the leave was granted, the insurer amalgamated with another companypany called the Hindustan Ideal insurance Company Ltd. and the latter companypany was substituted as the appellant

facts.text: The Andhra Insurance Co Ltd. was a composite insurance company doing life, fire and general insurance.

anchor.surface_text: MUDHOLKAR, J.-The Andhra Insurance Co Ltd.,  hereinafter called the Company  was a companyposite insurance companypany, that is, doing business in life insurance, fire insurance and general insurance.

facts.text: By s.7(1) of LIC Act 1956, all assets and liabilities pertaining to life insurance business transferred and vested in LIC on September 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of the Provisions of s. 7 1  of the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956  31 of 1956   hereinafter called the Act  all its assets and liabilities pertaining to the life insurance business stood transferred and vested in the Life Insurance Corporation on September 1, 1956.

facts.text: On February 14, 1957, Corporation wrote to Company offering Rs. 6,14,636 as compensation determined and approved by Central Government, with deductions of Rs. 3,76,117 for assets not transferred.

anchor.surface_text: On February 14, 1957, the Corporation wrote to the Company stating, among other things, that the amount of companypensation payable to it under s. 16 1  of the Act as determined by the Corporation and approved by the Central Government companyes to Rs. 6,14,636.

facts.text: Company accepted computation of compensation amount but disagreed over valuation of assets and objected to deduction of Rs. 3,76,117.

anchor.surface_text: while the Company accepted the companyputation of the amount of companypensation made by the Corporation there was disagreement between the parties over the valuation of the assets of the Company which stood transferred to the Corporation.

facts.text: On August 6, 1957, Company preferred petition of appeal before Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually on August 6, 1957 the Company preferred a petition of appeal before the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur, companystituted by the Central Government under s. 17 1  of the Act.

facts.text: On September 21, 1957, Company lodged statement of claim before Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: On September 21, 1957 the Company lodged its statement of claim before the Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal dismissed claim on basis of issue No.3 that claim barred by time under r.12.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal framed 27 issues but it gave its findings only on the first three issues and dismissed the claim. ... That issue is whether the claim of the Company is barred by time.

facts.text: Special leave to appeal granted by Supreme Court on August 18, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the decision of the Tribunal the Company moved this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution for grant of special leave to appeal. Leave was granted by this Court on August 18, 1958.

facts.text: Company amalgamated with Hindustan Ideal Insurance Co. Ltd. pursuant to scheme sanctioned by High Court of Andhra Pradesh, substituted as appellant on April 14, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent to the grant of leave by this Court the Company in pursuance of its scheme sanctioned by the High Court of Andhra Pradesh was amalgamated with the Hindustan Ideal Insurance Co., Ltd. By reason of this the letter has number been substituted as appellant under the orders of this Court dated April 14, 1959.

facts.text: Life Insurance Tribunal constituted by Central Government under s.17(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur, companystituted by the Central Government under s. 17 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Corporation resisted the claim on various grounds and filed written statement.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation resisted the claim out forward by the Company on various grounds.

facts.text: Petitioner contended Tribunal not appointed before expiry of 3 months in r.12, so limitation not commence till constitution; alternatively extend time under proviso.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant Mr. B.K.B. Naidu companytended that since the Tribunal itself wag number appointed before the expiry of the period of three months provided in r. 12, the claim made by the Company cannot be treated, as barred by time

facts.text: Respondent contended insurer cannot approach Tribunal directly, must move Corporation within 3 months for reference under s.16(2) and r.12.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the Corporation Mr. S. T. Desai companytended that under sub-s.2 of s. 16 it was number open to ,in insurer like the Company to prefer a claim directly before the Tribunal and that all that the law entitled the Company to do was to move the Corporation to make a reference
Aggrieved by the decision of the Tribunal the Company moved this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution for grant of special leave to appeal. Leave was granted by this Court on August 18, 1958.

arguments.claim: Proviso to r.12 indicates reference made by insurer etc., who can show sufficient cause

anchor.surface_text: But companysidering the rule along with the proviso it would appear that the rule was meant to govern a reference by someone else and number the Corporation.

arguments.claim: Proceedings before Tribunal incompetent as no reference by Corporation; insurer can move Corporation after time prescribed

anchor.surface_text: The proceedings before the Tribunal were misconceived because the only way in which they companyld be initiated was by a reference by the Corporation and there was numbersuch reference. No question of limitation arises because the period within which an insurer Must move the Corporation to make a reference has number yet been prescribed

holdings.text: An insurer has no right under section 16 to approach the Tribunal directly; the Tribunal can be moved by an insurer only through the Corporation which must refer the dispute to the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious from the terms of sub-sec. (2) of s. 16, and it is indeed not seriously in dispute, that the Tribunal can be, moved by an insurer only through the Corporation. An insurer has no right under the section to approach the Tribunal directly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.16(2) requires the insurer to 'have the matter referred to the Tribunal'; context of Act shows reference by Corporation, not direct approach by insurer.

holdings.text: The proceedings before the Tribunal were wholly misconceived and incompetent as there was no reference by the Corporation; no relief can be granted.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case however the insurer had directly moved the Tribunal. This it had no right to do. The proceedings commenced by it were therefore wholly misconceived. That being so, the insurer could not have obtained any relief from the Tribunal nor could the Tribunal have granted it any relief.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application invalidates jurisdiction; only reference by Corporation initiates valid proceedings.

holdings.text: No time has been prescribed under s.16(2) for the insurer to move the Corporation to refer the matter to the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government has not at any rate specifically prescribed the period within which the insurer has to move the Corporation for referring its claim to the Tribunal for decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.16(2) requires explicit prescription by rules; cl.(f) s.48(2) and r.12 do not specify time for moving Corporation.

holdings.text: Rule 12 prescribes the time within which a reference may be made to the Tribunal by the insurer, chief agent or special agent, not by the Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Now r. 12 of the Rule framed under the Act provides for the time within which a reference may be made to the Tribunal in respect of the determination of compensation payable under the Act. ... But considering the rule along with the proviso it would appear that the rule was meant to govern a reference by someone else and not the Corporation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso empowers Tribunal to extend time if 'person making the reference' shows cause; sub-rules apply to insurer etc.; avoids redundancy.

holdings.text: Rule 12 does not prescribe the time-limit within which the insurer must move the Corporation for reference.

anchor.surface_text: Prescribing time for making a reference is not prescribing time for moving the Corporation to make the reference. ... the proviso to r. 12 empowers the Tribunal to admit a reference after the period of limitation prescribed therefor if the person making the reference satisfies the Tribunal that he had sufficient cause for not making the reference within the prescribed period.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.16(2) mandates specific prescription for insurer's action; r.12 concerns reference itself, not preliminary motion to Corporation; proviso confirms.

holdings.text: Even if the insurer were entitled to move the Tribunal directly under the proviso to r.12, no sufficient cause was shown for extending time.

anchor.surface_text: If it is contended that the insurer was entitled to move the Tribunal directly under this proviso and had in fact done so, then, I think, it must be held that the Tribunal was right in its view that no cause had been shown by the insurer why time should be extended.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical assumption; Tribunal correctly found no cause shown, no interference warranted.

holdings.text: No question of limitation under r.12 arises as proceedings incompetent and no time prescribed under s.16(2).

anchor.surface_text: No question of limitation arises because the period within which an insurer must move the Corporation to make a reference has not yet been prescribed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdictional defect primary; limitation irrelevant without valid initiation; time not prescribed anyway.

holdings.text: The insurer/appellant remains entitled to move the Corporation under s.16(2) after the requisite period is prescribed.

anchor.surface_text: It will be open to the Appellant to move the Corporation under s. 16(2) after such period is prescribed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of prescription leaves right intact; future motion possible post-rule-making.

anchor.surface_text: In the West Derby Union v. Metropolitn Life Assurance Co Lord Watson observed I perfectly admit that there may be and are any oases which the terms of ail intelligible proviso may throw companysiderable  1   1897  A.C. 641, 652.

precedents.case_name: West Derby Union v. Metropolitn Life Assurance Co
precedents.cited_proposition: terms of an intelligible proviso may throw considerable light on the ambiguous import of the statutory words and a proviso may be a useful guide in the selection of one or other of two possible constructions of words in the enactment or to show the scope of the latter in a doubtful case
precedents.cited_holding: I perfectly admit that there may be and are any oases which the terms of ail intelligible proviso may throw companysiderable light on the ambiguous import of the statutory words. ... a proviso may be a useful guide in the selection of one or other of two possible companystructions of words in the enactment or to show the scope of the latter in a doubtful case.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed as proceedings before the Tribunal were wholly misconceived and incompetent since insurer had no right to approach Tribunal directly; no relief granted to appellant

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious from the terms of sub-sec. (2) of s. 16, and it is indeed not seriously in dispute, that the Tribunal can be, moved by an insurer only through the Corporation. An insurer has no right under the section to approach the Tribunal directly.
